text:
Police say blonde driver could provide answers to why woman at zebra crossing was left in a coma By Devon Live   By Gayle McDonald and Charlotte Turner 0 COMMENTS SHARES Comments (0) 
A blonde driver could hold vital information about the terrifying moment a woman was mowed down at a zebra crossing in Plymouth. Anna Davies, aged 45, remains in a coma after she was struck by a Fiat Punto on Albert Road on May 13 - more than a month ago. Read more A special group of women will be honoured at Exeter Armed Forces... 
Anna Davies remains in a coma 
Police have today issued a fresh appeal for anyone who witnessed the collision to come forward, the Plymouth Herald reports . 
In particular, they are hoping to speak to a slim blonde woman who was driving behind the car that struck Anna. 
PC Dave Stephenson, of the Serious Collisions Investigation Team, said: "We are specifically appealing to a potential witness who is described as a white female of slim build with long blonde coloured hair and aged between 45 and 55-years-old. 
"It is believed that she was the driver of a dark coloured car that was behind the car that was involved in the collision with the female pedestrian. 
"This blonde female took possession of a person's mobile phone and spoke to the emergency operator. 
"We are appealing to her to come forward as a potential witness." 
The crash happened at about 1.10pm 
The collision happened at the Pheasant Pluckers pub at about 1.10pm on Saturday, May 13. 
At the time, an officer said Anna was believed to have walked out in front of a car, which was not travelling at speed at the time of the collision. 
Any witnesses are urged to contact police by calling the non-emergency 101 telephone number, quoting the log number 420/13/05. Fundraising appeal for Anna 
An online appeal has been set up to raise money to support Anna and her family . 
Fleur Davies said her sister was on her way to voluntary job at Cancer Research when she was hit. 
She said the 45-year-old was left with brain damage following the crash and had to have part of her skull removed to help with the swelling on her brain. 
The family have cleared out Anna's second-floor flat and paid for her belongings to be put in storage because it is unlikely she will be able to climb two flights of stairs or live independently, if she wakes up. 
Any left over money from the appeal will go towards any care help Anna may need. 
Did you witness the collision? Read more Devon businesses told to speak out on Brexit 
Fleur, from St Budeaux, said: "We are taking each day as it comes but it is absolutely devastating." 
She added: "Anna is a really outgoing, talkative person, she would help anyone and give someone her very last penny. She was a carer for many years and loved it. 
"We hope she will be fine, we can't bear to think of any other outcome." 
The family is urging any witnesses to come forward. 
Fleur said: "Every penny helps but more than anything we want another witness to come forward as it's going to be three to four months before we find out more information from the police." 
To help Anna and her family, go to gofundme.com/gzd9n-help-for-anna .
